elements.content: The self-assembly of Rh(I) carbonyl and bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane (dpphex) ligands yields polymers with the general formula [RhCl(CO)(dpphex)]∞, obtained in two crystalline polymorphs characterized by one-dimensional networks segregated in layers to produce channels occupied by guest molecules (solvent). We report here simple methods to grow single crystals of these species, whereas all previous attempts using the same class of ligands and a variety of metal moieties were unsuccessful. The length of the alkyl chains is very important to produce suitable cavities of a host–guest system. The chain flexibility allows the solids to undergo crystal-to-crystal transformations upon the removal of the guest molecules and produce a new framework without cavities. However, without special precaution, the crystallinity appears to be fairly reduced, and it is impossible to revert the process preserving a single crystal and test the porosity properties of the material. On the other hand, at high temperatures, a recrystallization phenomenon is observed just before the melting point. The use of complementary techniques, such as polarizing microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and differential scanning calorimetry, provides some insights into the mechanics and the dynamics of the solid–solid transformations, both at the microscopic and molecular levels.

elements.content: The solid-state behavior of polymers obtained by self-assembly of Rh(I) carbonyl and bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane is studied through X-ray diffraction, optical microscopy in polarized light, and calorimetry. Crystal-to-crystal transformations and a recrystallization phenomenon are reported.

elements.content: In the search of new metal organic materials acting as gas or liquid reserves, we started a systematic investigation to ascertain whether chemical reactivity could also be stimulated, for example, by creating catalytic sites inside coordination networks. By using the intuitive approach of metal organic frameworks, the result can be achieved by coupling metal–carbonyl clusters and flexible organic bridges, for example, bis-phosphines. Both types of building blocks have not been exploited much so far, despite being promising. In fact, one could couple a metal cluster with the expected chemical reactivity and an alkyl chain able to model the framework structure for the selection and exchange of the guest molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the search of new metal organic materials acting as gas or liquid reserves, we started a systematic investigation to ascertain whether chemical reactivity could also be stimulated, for example, by creating catalytic sites inside coordination networks. By using the intuitive approach of metal organic frameworks, the result can be achieved by coupling metal-carbonyl clusters and flexible organic bridges, for example, bis-phosphines. Both types of building blocks have not been exploited much so far, despite being promising. In fact, one could couple a metal cluster with the expected chemical reactivity and an alkyl chain able to model the framework structure for the selection and exchange of the guest molecules.

elements.content: Focusing on the ligands, we noted that aliphatic bis(diphenyl)posphines have not been investigated so far for this purpose, besides being commercially available. To test their ability to give porous compounds, we first investigated their behavior in simple coordination polymers with mononuclear metal centers. This may lead to just one-dimensional (1D) polymers, perhaps efficiently packed through secondary interactions to form porous compounds. In a previous study, some of us demonstrated that Rh(I) or Ir(I) halo-carbonyl compounds and rigid bis(diphenylphosphino) ligands, such as 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)acetylene (dppa) or trans-1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethene (dppethe), are useful building blocks in the self-assembly of 1D coordination polymers. In all these structures, parallel chains of the metal−organic polymers are segregated in planes, the bis-phosphines being coordinated to the square planar metal in trans configuration. However, dppa and dppethe are inadequate to produce porous materials; hence, we searched for longer and flexible chains based on bis-phosphine-alkanes, which should favor the expansion−contraction of the crystalline lattice and produce an efficient host–guest system. The formation of a polymer is, however, contrasted by the tendency to chelate one metal instead of bridging two centers or by the formation of a finite cyclic molecule instead of an infinite open chain. Therefore, an accurate inspection of the chemistry of Rh(I) and bis-phosphine ligands was necessary to select the most appropriate bridge. The aliphatic bis-diphenylphosphines attracted much attention in the past few years owing to their possible catalytic activity. Derivatives of bis(diphenylphosphino)methane have been extensively studied, but less attention has been paid to complexes of Ph2P(CH2) n PPh2 (with n > 2). Bis-phosphines Ph2P(CH2) n PPh2 (n = 1, 3, and 4) usually bridge rhodium atoms; in fact, complexes with the general formula [RhCl(CO)(Ph2P(CH2) n PPh2)] m (n = 1–4) are all dimeric (i.e., m = 2) with a square planar geometry and a trans configuration at the rhodium atom (Scheme a). The only exception is 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane, which chelates the metal inducing a cis configuration (Scheme b). Bis-phosphines with longer aliphatic chains, such as t Bu2P(CH2)10P t Bu2, bridge Rh(I) or Pd(II) atoms but chelate Ir(I) or Pt(II) atoms in a trans manner.

So far, the complex with n = 6 has not been extensively studied, although it probably has the ideal length to bridge metal atoms of different molecules, leading to polymeric chains as suggested by McAuliffe et al. They studied Pd(II) complexes with some α,ω-bis(diphenylphosphino)alkanes Ph2P(CH2) n PPh2 (n = 6, 8, 10, and 12) and reported the formation of an insoluble product, presumably polymeric, for n = 6. Similarly, the reaction of [Rh(cyclo-octadiene)Cl]2 and 1,6-bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane, in the presence of CO, leads to a highly insoluble product. All these observations convinced us that 1,6-bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane (dpphex) could be the best ligand for our purposes.

Similarly, the reaction of [Rh(cyclo-octadiene)Cl]2 and 1,6-bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane, in the presence of CO, leads to a highly insoluble product. All these observations convinced us that 1,6-bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane (dpphex) could be the best ligand for our purposes.

elements.content: As anticipated, our target building blocks are transition metal clusters that, apart from the tunable reactivity, might behave as tri- or tetraconnected nodes, hence increasing the framework dimensionality. However, our first step was to test the coordination at a single metal site; thus, we report here on the synthesis of a new polymer obtained by self-assembly of dpphex and [PPh4][RhCl2(CO)2] (i.e., a source of Rh(I), prompted for bicoordination). A careful optimization of the procedure was necessary to obtain single crystals, a result that was not obtained in previous studies on these compounds.
elements.clean_text: As anticipated, our target building blocks are transition metal clusters that, apart from the tunable reactivity, might behave as tri- or tetraconnected nodes, hence increasing the framework dimensionality. However, our first step was to test the coordination at a single metal site; thus, we report here on the synthesis of a new polymer obtained by self-assembly of dpphex and [PPh4][RhCl2(CO)2] (i.e., a source of Rh(I), prompted for bicoordination). A careful optimization of the procedure was necessary to obtain single crystals, a result that was not obtained in previous studies on these compounds.

elements.content: Once crystalline polymeric species were obtained, we focused on the structural characterization and the transformations occurring upon loss of the guest molecules (solvent) or external perturbations (such as temperature gradients, gas pressure, etc.). For a more comprehensive characterization, we adopted the following complementary techniques: (a) X-ray diffraction for the determination and recognition of the crystalline phases, (b) polarizing microscopy to observe the transformations of the crystalline samples, and (c) modulated temperature differential scanning calorimetry to measure the thermodynamics of the phenomena detected by microscopic techniques.
elements.clean_text: Once crystalline polymeric species were obtained, we focused on the structural characterization and the transformations occurring upon loss of the guest molecules (solvent) or external perturbations (such as temperature gradients, gas pressure, etc.). For a more comprehensive characterization, we adopted the following complementary techniques: (a) X-ray diffraction for the determination and recognition of the crystalline phases, (b) polarizing microscopy to observe the transformations of the crystalline samples, and (c) modulated temperature differential scanning calorimetry to measure the thermodynamics of the phenomena detected by microscopic techniques.

elements.content:
The interesting results obtained prompted us to report on the microscopic and structural investigations in due course and focus on the catalytic properties of these materials in further works.

Experimental SectionSynthesis

All operations were carried out under N2 by using Schlenk tube techniques. Tetrahydrofuran was distilled from Na-naphthalene-chetile; all other analytical-grade solvents were degassed and stored under N2. The ATR-IR spectra were recorded on single crystals, using an FT-IR Thermo Nicolet Avatar 360 instrument equipped with the Smart Endurance accessory. [PPh4][RhCl2(CO)2] was prepared following the literature procedure, only slightly modified.

Synthesis

elements.content:
1,6-Bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane was purchased from Aldrich and used without any further purification.

Synthesis of [RhCl(CO)(<italic toggle="yes">dpphex</italic>)·(<italic toggle="yes">solvent</italic>)]

A dichloromethane solution of [PPh4][RhCl2(CO)2] (74 mg, 0.13 mmol in 2.5 mL) was layered under N2 atmosphere with a tetrahydrofuran solution of dpphex (122 mg, 0.27 mmol in 2.5 mL). ATR-IR: ν̃ cm−1 (CO) 1956 (sh) (Found C, 56.30; H, 5.30; C32H34Cl3OP2Rh requires C, 55.19; H, 4.89).
elements.clean_text:
1,6-Bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane was purchased from Aldrich and used without any further purification.

Synthesis of [RhCl(CO)(dpphex)⋅(solvent)]

A dichloromethane solution of [PPh4][RhCl2(CO)2] (74 mg, 0.13 mmol in 2.5 mL) was layered under N2 atmosphere with a tetrahydrofuran solution of dpphex (122 mg, 0.27 mmol in 2.5 mL). ATR-IR: ν̃ cm-1 (CO) 1956 (sh) (Found C, 56.30; H, 5.30; C32H34Cl3OP2Rh requires C, 55.19; H, 4.89).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out using a Bruker SMART APEX2 diffractometer equipped with an Oxford Cryosystem liquid-N2 cryostream (600 series) with the generator working at 50 kV and 30 mA. A Mo Kα radiation from fine focus sealed tubes, 0.5 mm collimated, was used. Details of each data collection are given in Table . The raw integrated intensities of all data sets were corrected for crystal anisotropies with the SADABS program, and a spherical absorption correction was then applied. Structures were solved by using direct methods with SIR97 and refined with the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with the SHELX97 program (within the WINGX package). In all the structures, CO and Cl are mutually disordered, with an occupancy close to 50%. Disorder was found in the crystalline species 3a between the two solvents (THF and CH2Cl2), the occupancy of which was fixed at 50%. Bond-distance restraints were necessary for the structures of the crystalline species after the solvent removal. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to non-hydrogen atoms; however, for species 2b, 3c, and 4, many C atoms were refined isotropically because of the inconsistency of the anisitropic refinement. Hydrogen atoms were always modeled on the riding C atoms. The residual indices of each model refinement are given in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction Analysis

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out using a Bruker SMART APEX2 diffractometer equipped with an Oxford Cryosystem liquid-N2 cryostream (600 series) with the generator working at 50 kV and 30 mA. A Mo Kα radiation from fine focus sealed tubes, 0.5 mm collimated, was used. Details of each data collection are given in Table . The raw integrated intensities of all data sets were corrected for crystal anisotropies with the SADABS program, and a spherical absorption correction was then applied. Structures were solved by using direct methods with SIR97 and refined with the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with the SHELX97 program (within the WINGX package). In all the structures, CO and Cl are mutually disordered, with an occupancy close to 50%. Disorder was found in the crystalline species 3a between the two solvents (THF and CH2Cl2), the occupancy of which was fixed at 50%. Bond-distance restraints were necessary for the structures of the crystalline species after the solvent removal. Anisotropic thermal parameters were assigned to non-hydrogen atoms; however, for species 2b, 3c, and 4, many C atoms were refined isotropically because of the inconsistency of the anisitropic refinement. Hydrogen atoms were always modeled on the riding C atoms. The residual indices of each model refinement are given in Table .

The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) diagrams were collected on a Bruker D8 diffractometer equipped with a Vantec detector, working at 40 kV and 40 mA and using a Cu Kα monochromatized radiation.

Microscopy

For the microscopic analysis, an Olympus BX52 microscope was used. It was equipped with a rotating plane-polarizer, a monochromatic (550 ± 10 nm) filter, a circular analyzer (i.e., a plane-polarizer and a quarter wave plate), and a Scion CFW-1310M B&W charge-coupled device camera. The temperature was controlled by a Linkam Hot stage. The images were analyzed with the software METRIPOL in order to extract the transmittance, the optic axis orientation, and the retardation images. The transmittance measured at any position within the image captured by the camera is given by the formula I   =   ( I 0 / 2 ) [ 1 + 2 sin ( 2 φ − 2 α ) sin ( δ ) ] where I 0 is the intensity of the light passing through the sample and represents its transmittance and φ is the angle of one axis of the optical indicatrix and α that of the plane-polarizer (both measured with respect to a given origin). δ is the phase shift introduced by the sample between the two orthogonal components of the polarized light δ = ( 2 π / λ ) Δ n τ where λ is the wavelength of the light and τ is the thickness and Δn the birefringence of the sample. By measuring several images while varying the angle α, it is possible to compute at each pixel in the image the quantities |sin(δ)|, I 0, and φ. Therefore, each image (usually obtained by moving the polarizer to 10 positions) can be decomposed in three different pictures: (1) the orientation of one indicatrix axis (φ), (2) the retardation (|sin(δ)|), and (3) the transmittance (I 0). The orientation and retardation are shown in false colors, which represent the different values of the φ angle (0−180°) and |sin(δ)| (0−1) (only the orientation images are presented in this work, and the corresponding color scale is given in the ). The transmittance images are shown in a gray scale (ranging from 0 to 100% transmittance).

Microscopy

For the microscopic analysis, an Olympus BX52 microscope was used. elements.content: The purpose of this work was not to determine the absolute birefringence of the compounds; therefore, the accurate measuring of the sample thickness was not carried out, and the retardation images were used only for the qualitative analysis of the transformation occurring in the crystalline samples. The orientation images have, in principle, an immediate connection with the crystalline structure. However, this is mainly true for uniaxial systems (namely tetragonal and trigonal/hexagonal lattices), where the optic axis is oriented along the main crystallographic axis. On the other hand, in biaxial systems (triclinic, monoclinic, and orthorhombic), the orientation of the optic plane (which contains the two secondary optic axis directions) is not so straightforward. For the samples of species 2a and 3a, we could carry out observations only on one face, given the flat shape of the crystal habit and the strong absorption in all the other directions. For the species 3a (monoclinic), the face observed in all the micrographs reported in this work is (010), which could correspond either to the optic plane or to a plane perpendicular to it. For the species 2a (triclinic), there is no special connection between the crystallographic and optic directions. The face under observation, (001), regularly shows birefringence; therefore, we can only deduce that this face is not perpendicular to one of the two optic axes.

elements.content: The use of perfluoropolyether oil as a protective medium for the crystals certainly affects the orientation and retardation images because of its refracting index. As a matter of fact, any sample observed in this medium showed a modified orientation picture, the φ angle of which could also become ambiguous as that of a glass or any non-birefringent material. Thus, the orientation micrographs shown in this paper should not be considered as quantitative measures of the indicatrix orientation, but rather as qualitative observations of the changes occurring to the crystalline samples.

elements.content: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were performed on a TA Instruments Q100 DSC device, equipped with a liquid-N2 cooling-system device. Dry N2 gas with a flow rate of 50 mL/min was purged through the DSC cell. The baseline calibration was performed with an empty cell, heated to the same conditions as the subsequent sample runs. The temperature and heat flow were calibrated by using an indium standard. The heat capacity calibration constant for the modulation calibration was done by using standard sapphire samples. Sample masses of about 3−10 mg were used. MDSC experiments were carried out from 40 to 300 °C by using a heating rate of 5 °C/min (by using a heating-only procedure). All the data were analyzed with the TA Universal Analysis 2000 program.
elements.clean_text:
Temperature Modulated Differential Scanning Calorimetry (MDSC)

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements were performed on a TA Instruments Q100 DSC device, equipped with a liquid-N2 cooling-system device. Dry N2 gas with a flow rate of 50 mL/min was purged through the DSC cell. The baseline calibration was performed with an empty cell, heated to the same conditions as the subsequent sample runs. The temperature and heat flow were calibrated by using an indium standard. The heat capacity calibration constant for the modulation calibration was done by using standard sapphire samples. Sample masses of about 3-10 mg were used. MDSC experiments were carried out from 40 to 300 °C by using a heating rate of 5 °C/min (by using a heating-only procedure). All the data were analyzed with the TA Universal Analysis 2000 program.

elements.content: The addition of dpphex to a dichloromethane solution of the metal–carbonyl compound gave a very sparingly soluble yellow powder. Crystals suitable for the X-ray and the microscopic analyses were grown by layering the metal−complex solution with one of the ligands in C4H8O (THF), under a N2 atmosphere. After few minutes, the color between the two solutions became dark yellow, and the gas evolution was observed. After 24 h, the first crystals were clearly visible. The product was nearly insoluble in many solvents such as THF, CH2Cl2, acetone, CH3CN, alcohols, and toluene. The IR spectrum of the crystals showed, in the carbonyl region, only one very sharp band at 1956 cm−1, which is typical for carbon monoxide trans to chloride in square planar Rh(I) complexes. n [PP h 4 ][RhCl 2 (CO ) 2 ]    +    n ( d p p h e x ) → [RhCl(CO)( dpphex )] n + n [PP h 4 ] Cl   +   n CO
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation of [RhCl(CO)(dpphex)⋅(solvent)]∞ 

The addition of dpphex to a dichloromethane solution of the metal-carbonyl compound gave a very sparingly soluble yellow powder. Crystals suitable for the X-ray and the microscopic analyses were grown by layering the metal-complex solution with one of the ligands in C4H8O (THF), under a N2 atmosphere. After few minutes, the color between the two solutions became dark yellow, and the gas evolution was observed. After 24 h, the first crystals were clearly visible. The product was nearly insoluble in many solvents such as THF, CH2Cl2, acetone, CH3CN, alcohols, and toluene. The IR spectrum of the crystals showed, in the carbonyl region, only one very sharp band at 1956 cm-1, which is typical for carbon monoxide trans to chloride in square planar Rh(I) complexes.  1     n   [PP   h   4   ][RhCl   2   (CO   )   2   ]   +   n ( d p p h e x ) →   [RhCl(CO)( dpphex )]   n   +   n [PP   h   4   ] Cl   +  n CO

elements.content: Under the optical microscope, several crystal morphologies were recognized. Some of them were quite instable outside the mother liquors, and they clearly lost transparency and, visually judging, crystallinity in a few minutes. After the single-crystal X-ray analysis, three different structures were identified: a cyclic dimeric complex (1a), a side product that contrasted the formation of the polymer (see above) and is of course less interesting for the purposes of our study, and two polymorphs of the 1D polymeric network (2a and 3a).
elements.clean_text: Under the optical microscope, several crystal morphologies were recognized. Some of them were quite instable outside the mother liquors, and they clearly lost transparency and, visually judging, crystallinity in a few minutes. After the single-crystal X-ray analysis, three different structures were identified: a cyclic dimeric complex (1a), a side product that contrasted the formation of the polymer (see above) and is of course less interesting for the purposes of our study, and two polymorphs of the 1D polymeric network (2a and 3a).

elements.content: The two polymorphs have the general formula [RhCl(CO)(dpphex)·(solvent)]∞, where solvent is CH2Cl2 in 2a and a mixture of CH2Cl2 and THF in 3a. All the species come from the neutral product of the substitution reaction occurring at the metal center, where two P atoms belonging to two different phosphines replace one CO molecule and one Cl atom per Rh atom. The dimeric form 1a, namely [RhCl(CO)(dpphex)]2·[CH2Cl2]3, differs from the polymers simply because the two dpphex molecules bind the same two metal centers. Thus, there is a formal relation of ring-opening polymerization between the cyclic dimer and the polymer. In fact, one could obtain the repeating unit of the polymer just by breaking one of the Rh−P bonds of the dimer (see Scheme ). Whether 1a can really be a precursor to the polymer in the solution is the object of investigation currently carried out in our laboratories.

Thus, there is a formal relation of ring-opening polymerization between the cyclic dimer and the polymer. In fact, one could obtain the repeating unit of the polymer just by breaking one of the Rh-P bonds of the dimer (see Scheme ). Whether 1a can really be a precursor to the polymer in the solution is the object of investigation currently carried out in our laboratories.

We repeated the synthesis by trying different experimental conditions, varying the molar concentration from 10−1 to 10−3 M and the metal/bis-phosphine molar ratio from 1:1 to 1:3. In all the attempts, we were unable to obtain only one species, but there was always some amount of dimer together with the two polymeric forms. Unfortunately, a quantitative analysis of the products to determine the actual yields of each preparation was not possible because the solvent was easily lost upon grounding the polymers that collapsed into the same solvent-less phase of lower crystallinity (vide infra). Visually judging, however, we could estimate that all the preparations made with high concentrations of reagents gave polymeric species (almost pure in some circumstances), whereas the dimeric molecule was in excess when low concentrations were used.

Unfortunately, a quantitative analysis of the products to determine the actual yields of each preparation was not possible because the solvent was easily lost upon grounding the polymers that collapsed into the same solvent-less phase of lower crystallinity (vide infra). Visually judging, however, we could estimate that all the preparations made with high concentrations of reagents gave polymeric species (almost pure in some circumstances), whereas the dimeric molecule was in excess when low concentrations were used.

elements.content: During the microscopic analysis, at least three kinds of morphologies were recognized (see Figure ): (I) almost regular rectangular prisms, (II) flat prisms with a distorted hexagonal basal face (sometimes broken into smaller prisms with a trapezoid base), and (III) flat prisms with a distorted rhombic basal face (sometimes with two extra edges).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

During the microscopic analysis, at least three kinds of morphologies were recognized (see Figure ): (I) almost regular rectangular prisms, (II) flat prisms with a distorted hexagonal basal face (sometimes broken into smaller prisms with a trapezoid base), and (III) flat prisms with a distorted rhombic basal face (sometimes with two extra edges).

elements.content: Most relevant crystalline morphologies observed in the reaction product of [RhCl2(CO)2]− and dpphex assembly.
elements.clean_text: 1  Most relevant crystalline morphologies observed in the reaction product of [RhCl2(CO)2]- and dpphex assembly.

elements.content: Because the polymeric species were quite instable after the extraction from their mother liquors, we immersed them in a perfluoro-polyether oil and performed the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis at a moderately low temperature. This allowed us to obtain good-quality information on their crystalline structure. The dimer 1a crystallizes as triclinic in prisms of the form I, whereas the polymeric species 2a is triclinic with a crystal habit II and 3a is monoclinic with a habit III.
elements.clean_text: Because the polymeric species were quite instable after the extraction from their mother liquors, we immersed them in a perfluoro-polyether oil and performed the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis at a moderately low temperature. This allowed us to obtain good-quality information on their crystalline structure. The dimer 1a crystallizes as triclinic in prisms of the form I, whereas the polymeric species 2a is triclinic with a crystal habit II and 3a is monoclinic with a habit III.

elements.content: In all the structures, the square planar Rh(I) atom bears two phosphine ligands in trans configuration. The two remaining sites are occupied by CO and Cl, which are always mutually disordered about the metal center. The phosphine ligands are free to rotate about the Rh−P bond, and their conformation about this axis is such that an eclipsing with CO or Cl ligands at Rh is always avoided. On the other hand, the two trans dpphex groups may adopt either a staggered or an eclipsed conformation about the P---P axis (the P−Rh−P angle is 180° by symmetry in 2a and 3a or very close to 180° in 1a (). In the staggered conformation, the alkyl chains could be anti-periplanar or syn-clinal, whereas they can be either mutually eclipsed (syn-periplanar) or not (anticlinal) in the eclipsed form (Figure ). This variety of conformations might generate different supramolecular architectures (supramolecular isomerism), although we have observed only two of them: the eclipsed syn-periplanar (see Figure d), which favors the formation of dimeric species because the two alkyl chains are eclipsed and the two PPh2 end-chain groups prompted to bind the very same Rh(CO)(Cl) unit and (b) the staggered anti-periplanar conformation, which implies a 1D polymeric network, as observed for both 2a and 3a.

On the other hand, the two trans dpphex groups may adopt either a staggered or an eclipsed conformation about the P---P axis (the P-Rh-P angle is 180° by symmetry in 2a and 3a or very close to 180° in 1a (). In the staggered conformation, the alkyl chains could be anti-periplanar or syn-clinal, whereas they can be either mutually eclipsed (syn-periplanar) or not (anticlinal) in the eclipsed form (Figure ). This variety of conformations might generate different supramolecular architectures (supramolecular isomerism), although we have observed only two of them: the eclipsed syn-periplanar (see Figure d), which favors the formation of dimeric species because the two alkyl chains are eclipsed and the two PPh2 end-chain groups prompted to bind the very same Rh(CO)(Cl) unit and (b) the staggered anti-periplanar conformation, which implies a 1D polymeric network, as observed for both 2a and 3a.

elements.content: Ball and stick representation of the four conformations that could be adopted by the dpphex ligands about the P−Rh−P axis: (a) eclipsed anticlinal, (b) staggered anti-periplanar (found in polymers 2 and 3), (c) staggered syn-clinal, and (d) eclipsed syn-periplanar (found in the dimer 1a). The dpphex chain is truncated at the third C atom in all drawings. C atoms of the alkyl chains are in blue, C atoms of the phenyl ring in gray, C and O atoms of the carbonyl in red, Cl atoms in green, and P atoms in orange.

elements.content: Because of the antiperiplanar conformation, the 1D networks of both 2a and 3a adopt a zigzag shape, see Figure . The chains are packed parallel to each other in a plane ([001] and [010] for 2a and 3a, respectively), thus producing a segregation of the solvent molecules in layers. Actually, because of the hook-and-loop interaction between phenyl rings belonging to different layers of polymers, small channels containing the solvent are identified. Also, no special bonding interaction but the zigzag shape itself forces the chains to compact in a plane; the crystals are mainly grown along the two directions of the layers, whereas the alternation of polymer and solvent layers is a less favorable interaction, which explains the quite flat crystal habit of both polymorphs.
elements.clean_text: Because of the antiperiplanar conformation, the 1D networks of both 2a and 3a adopt a zigzag shape, see Figure . The chains are packed parallel to each other in a plane ([001] and [010] for 2a and 3a, respectively), thus producing a segregation of the solvent molecules in layers. Actually, because of the hook-and-loop interaction between phenyl rings belonging to different layers of polymers, small channels containing the solvent are identified. Also, no special bonding interaction but the zigzag shape itself forces the chains to compact in a plane; the crystals are mainly grown along the two directions of the layers, whereas the alternation of polymer and solvent layers is a less favorable interaction, which explains the quite flat crystal habit of both polymorphs.

elements.content: The dimeric species 1a, instead, contains rectangular rings (each P atom being at one vertex, see Figure ) disposed almost parallel to [100] and packed to form a layer, therefore segregating the solvent. The habit of these species is however quite different from that of 2a and 3a, being almost equivalently grown in all directions (see Figure ).

The habit of these species is however quite different from that of 2a and 3a, being almost equivalently grown in all directions (see Figure ).

elements.content: The conformations about the C−C bonds of the hexane chains in 2a and 3a are always trans, thus producing the longest extension of dpphex ligand (corresponding to a P---P distance of ca. 9.5 Å), which allows a lot of room to host the clathrated solvent molecules. In 1a, there is a slight distortion from the perfect trans conformations because of the mild strain induced by the ring structure (the P---P distance is therefore slightly smaller, ca. 9.2 Å).

elements.content: We decided to investigate how the process of solvent loss affects the crystalline structure, both at the molecular and microscopic levels. We therefore tried to identify any additional crystalline phase produced and eventually to analyze the solid-state form and the behavior of the polymers after the complete removal of the guest molecules. Moreover, we tested the ability of the species to reinclude the solvent or even the gas molecules, perhaps by means of oxidative addition.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Modifications

We decided to investigate how the process of solvent loss affects the crystalline structure, both at the molecular and microscopic levels. We therefore tried to identify any additional crystalline phase produced and eventually to analyze the solid-state form and the behavior of the polymers after the complete removal of the guest molecules. Moreover, we tested the ability of the species to reinclude the solvent or even the gas molecules, perhaps by means of oxidative addition.

elements.content: Because the solvent left the host quite rapidly, crystals observed under the microscope were usually immersed in the protective oil. At room temperature, this does not prevent the evaporation process but it significantly reduces its kinetics. In this way, we could monitor the changes occurring to the crystals of type 2a or 3a in a polarized light. Thanks to the METRIPOL imaging technique, we could associate the transmittance images with the optic indicatrix orientation and retardation images (see ), which was useful to monitor the evolution of one phase into another and whether the sample was preserving its single-crystalline nature or not. The orientation and retardation images emphasize the inner changes occurring in a crystal more than a simple direct image, because they are sensitive to the reorganization of the crystal structure and to the actual amount of matter illuminated. The orientation pictures are displayed in false colors and scaled with respect to one indicatrix axis orientation. For example, in Figure , it is possible to observe the change occurring to a sample of species 2a in about 1 h. At the beginning, the crystal does not show any special orientation, having the same color as the background (purple in the micrographs of Figure ), because the refraction through the oil quenches the actual birefringence of the crystal. However, as the solvent leaves the solid, the oil is removed from the sample surface, and an orientation different from that of the background is observed. These images demonstrate that the solvent exits either from face [001] (which is progressively cleaned) or from faces perpendicular to that (as the sudden formation of bubbles in the oil is observed; for example, in Figure , it is visible that a small crystalline fragment, on the right side of the crystal, is moved by the solvent flow during the experiment). The almost uniform color of the orientation image at the end of the process suggests that the solid has eventually preserved its single-crystalline nature. As a matter of fact, we could mount the very same crystal on the diffractometer and determine its modified crystalline structure (2b). The system is again triclinic, though with a different metric and containing only one-half of the original amount of solvent. The same experiment was carried out on a crystal without the protective oil (Figure ). Here, the birefringence is not affected by the oil, and the initial orientation image appears with a given orientation angle; hence, a false color, different from that of the background, is observed. After a few minutes, the sample is no longer uniform and shows large zones of background signal indicating very small crystalline or even amorphous domains and others where the orientation is not homogeneous. This suggests that the single-crystalline nature was not preserved, as proved by the lack of single-crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: Similar experiments were carried out with crystals of 3a. Again, the loss of solvent was visible under the polarized light, but it was not possible to obtain a solvent-free sample suitable for the X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis. We have only been able to observe the elevation of the crystal symmetry from monoclinic P to monoclinic C (3b), occurring upon heating a sample (up to 330 K) directly on the diffractometer. A model for 3b is not unambiguously refined; therefore, we report in Table only the information concerning the unit cell type and metrics (monoclinic, quite similar to 3a, but A-centered) which seems confirmed from reflection statistics. Of course, an alternative metrics could be a primitive triclinic.

elements.content: By chance, we were able to identify a solvent-free phase (3c) starting, however, from a crystal of the Ir(I) polymer. When immersed in its mother liquor (or in the protective oil), this sample was isomorphous with 3a. The transformation from 3a to 3c involves a monoclinic to triclinic change accompanied by a severe modification of the conformation about the C−C bonds of the hexane chains, since two of them become gauche; therefore, the chain is more contracted (in fact, the P---P distance is reduced to ca. 8.8 Å).

elements.content: For both 2a and 3a, the transmittance images clearly show how the crystals have been severely damaged by the solvent evaporation. Note that, in 2a, the main fractures (appearing in the initial stages) are approximately elongated in the direction (110), that is, the direction along which the network chains are extended (see Figure ). This might suggest that the path used by the guest molecules to leave from the [001] face implies breaking the polymer layers along their weakest linkage line (no covalent bond, nor any strong intermolecular interaction, is in fact bridging adjacent chains). On the other hand, the paths for lateral solvent loss could be the channels perpendicular to the planes [110] and [11̅0], where the guest molecules can flow more easily (although traveling for a longer path).

elements.content: The micrographs in Figure show two crystals (of species 2a and 3a). Their behavior outside the mother liquors is recorded over a few hours. The fractures in 2a occur more rapidly than in 3a. Not surprisingly, for all the species, the diffraction is quite affected after the crystal ruptures have occurred, but nevertheless sufficient to determine with a reasonable accuracy the structures of 2b and 3c.

elements.content: The loss of the guest molecules is obviously accompanied by a contraction of the volume, see Figure . In 3a, the solvent occupies about 480 Å3 per unit cell. Because the structure of 3c was determined from an Ir(I) isomorphous crystal, the volume contraction is apparently not so large. An additional reason is that the packing in 3c is not so efficient. However, by probing with a sphere of 1.1 Å radius, no space would be available for the solvent in 3c. The main shrinking occurs along the c-axis (corresponding to b in the monoclinic metrics of 3a), which is almost normal to the polymer layers. On the other hand, the triclinic 2a has one-half the unit cell content of 3a; therefore, only 220 Å3 are occupied by the solvent. The intermediate species 2b has a volume almost twice as large, but includes only one-half of the expected solvent molecules (associated with ca. 224 Å3). Again, the volume contraction between 2a and 2b (once we normalize for the content of monomer units) is less than expected and mainly affects the direction perpendicular to the layers.

elements.content: It is also interesting how the crystal network is modified upon the solvent loss. In fact, adjacent layers become closer as expected, but some contraction of the polymer chains is also observed, see Figure . Species 2b and 3b can be considered as intermediates, having some solvent molecules still included, and in fact, they display only a partial reorganization about the C−C bonds. On the basis of the crystal symmetry and packing of species 2a and 3a, one may suppose that 2b would eventually adopt a structure similar to that of 3c after the complete removal of the solvent. Unfortunately, despite several attempts, we have been unable to produce, starting from 2a, any single crystal isomorphous with 3c and therefore prove this conjecture. However, from X-ray diffraction of a powder, grinded from a sample containing crystal morphologies of both 2a and 3a and dried for a few days in the air, we were able to identify only one crystalline phase isomorphous with 3c (Figure ).

elements.content: Both 2 and 3 significantly reduce their crystallinity after the solvent molecules leave. The process can be stimulated by heating the samples at moderate temperatures (ca. 80–120 °C) for a few hours. The samples appear quite opaque and show mainly a background color in terms of orientation and retardation images under the polarizing microscope, which means that no birefringence is observable. This is of course a clear indication of the reduced size of the crystalline domains and an incipient amorphization.

elements.content: We thought that recrystallization processes, typical for example in organic amorphous polymers, could occur also in this kind of coordination networks. As a matter of fact, we observed under the polarizing microscope a distinct recrystallization phenomenon (giving a species that we can call 3d), occurring just before the melting at ca. 240–250 °C (see Figure for the sequence on species 2). On the other hand, the crystals of species 1a, even though containing a solvent that is lost at high temperature, do not go through an observable recrystallization; they simply melt.

elements.content: We tried to promote the recrystallization by cycling the polymeric samples close to the melting point and back to room temperature several times. One of these sequences is reproduced in Figure and shows the growth of the crystalline area of the sample. In fact, the region with an orientation significantly different from that of the background increases in size and extends over the whole sample after the final cycle.

Therefore, we could not investigate the solid-state form 2d by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis.

elements.content: On the other hand, the occurrence of recrystallization could be confirmed using the MDSC technique, which enables one to separate the reversible and irreversible heat exchanged during a temperature gradient. The melting of a crystalline species is of course a reversible endothermic phenomenon, whereas the recrystallization of an amorphous polymer is an irreversible exothermic process. We therefore tested in MDSC a powder originally composed of 2a and 3a, left in air for a few days. We first monitored the sample by XRPD, as reported in Figure , and checked that the major content was in fact the desolvated phase 3c. Afterward, we performed DSC and MDSC measurements. As we can see from Figure , the two endothermic peaks of the traditional DSC signal (i.e., the total heat exchanged, black curve) are actually composed of two reversible endothermic peaks (blue curve) and smaller exothermic and endothermic peaks of the irreversible heat (red curve). The recrystallization of the amorphous component into the crystalline species 3d, as observed in the micrographs of Figure , should therefore occur underneath the exothermic peak at ca. 240 °C (simultaneously with the melting). However, a more careful analysis shows two very broad exothermic peaks in the irreversible heat curve along the scan (above 100 °C), consistent with the increased crystallinity observed after the repeated warming−cooling cycles shown in Figure . The endothermic peak slightly above 250 °C could be instead assigned to the melting of the crystalline phase of 3c, perhaps associated with a partial decomposition, given the presence of a clear endothermic peak in the irreversible heat curve. The above result is also based on the observation that a fresh sample (i.e., put in the aluminum pan directly from the mother liquor) does not produce the melting/recrystallization peak at 240 °C, but only the melting peak at 250 °C, together with several irreversible endothermic peaks at lower temperatures (corresponding to a multistep loss of solvent, see ). We can justify this with the short time available to species 2a and 3a to transform into 3d (a process that requires sample aging). In fact, the temperature ramp of a DSC measurement cannot produce enough amorphous content; thus, the recrystallization into 3d cannot occur.

elements.content: Because our purpose was to test the ability of the bis-phosphine Rh(I) polymers to act as porous compounds, we tried to replace the guest molecules with gaseous H2 or with other solvent molecules. In principle, H2 could be captured by oxidative addition at Rh(I) centers, provided that the guest solvent is replaced. Thus, we placed a few crystals, previously immersed in their mother liquor, in an autoclave at 40 atm of H2 pressure at room temperature for three days. As a result, the crystals seemed to have darkened but were unaltered at X-ray analysis. A reduction to metallic Rh occurred, but only at the surface. Suspending the polymer in methanol and bubbling through a H2 gas had no effect at room temperature, whereas, at a higher temperature, it reduced the metallic centers to Rh(0).
elements.clean_text: Because our purpose was to test the ability of the bis-phosphine Rh(I) polymers to act as porous compounds, we tried to replace the guest molecules with gaseous H2 or with other solvent molecules. In principle, H2 could be captured by oxidative addition at Rh(I) centers, provided that the guest solvent is replaced. Thus, we placed a few crystals, previously immersed in their mother liquor, in an autoclave at 40 atm of H2 pressure at room temperature for three days. As a result, the crystals seemed to have darkened but were unaltered at X-ray analysis. A reduction to metallic Rh occurred, but only at the surface. Suspending the polymer in methanol and bubbling through a H2 gas had no effect at room temperature, whereas, at a higher temperature, it reduced the metallic centers to Rh(0).

elements.content: Then, we put some wet crystals into different solvents, such as toluene, cyclohexane, and acetone, and we left them in the solution for two months, refreshing the solvent every week and paying careful attention to leave them always well-dipped in the solution. Unfortunately, all the polymeric species lost their single-crystalline nature, and we could not verify that the exchange had occurred successfully. Only the cyclic dimer 1a exchanged the CH2Cl2 clathrated molecule within an acetone solution, forming [RhCl(CO)(dpphex)]2·((CH3)2CO) (4), as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. We did not observe any dissolution followed by recrystallization in the new solvent of the 1a samples. Instead, at the end of the treatment, the samples appeared quite similar to the initial stages, only slightly damaged but sufficiently single-crystalline for diffraction analysis.

elements.content: In this paper, we have reported on the self-assembly of [RhCl2(CO)2]− and bis-(diphenylphosphino)hexane to give 1D networks, fully characterized at the microscopic and molecular levels. Previous attempts to obtain polymeric species by using the same class of ligands in the form of single crystals have always failed, whereas we propose here simple methods for the growth of these crystals. There is some competition between cyclic molecules and polymeric species, but the synthesis can be driven toward the desired product in sufficient yields.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper, we have reported on the self-assembly of [RhCl2(CO)2]- and bis-(diphenylphosphino)hexane to give 1D networks, fully characterized at the microscopic and molecular levels. Previous attempts to obtain polymeric species by using the same class of ligands in the form of single crystals have always failed, whereas we propose here simple methods for the growth of these crystals. There is some competition between cyclic molecules and polymeric species, but the synthesis can be driven toward the desired product in sufficient yields.

elements.content: The ligand was selected with the purpose to synthesize the polymers characterized by robust coordination of fairly flexible organic ligands and by large channels in their structures to enhance the porosity and to test the reversibility of the exchange of guest molecules. The materials are in fact promising and certainly worth being further investigated. Although extended three-dimensional networks are not available with the engineering we adopted, some porous properties are observed because the material encapsulates the solvent molecules that are released without losing their crystallinity while modifying the polymer conformation and packing. However, this process is too fast, and the single-crystalline nature of the samples is easily lost, especially if they are left in air without vapors of the solvent or any special protection. The inverse process, namely, the solvent inclusion, is therefore not possible in single crystals, thus classifying these species as belonging to the first-generation type of porous coordination polymers, according to Kitagawa.
elements.clean_text: The ligand was selected with the purpose to synthesize the polymers characterized by robust coordination of fairly flexible organic ligands and by large channels in their structures to enhance the porosity and to test the reversibility of the exchange of guest molecules. The materials are in fact promising and certainly worth being further investigated. Although extended three-dimensional networks are not available with the engineering we adopted, some porous properties are observed because the material encapsulates the solvent molecules that are released without losing their crystallinity while modifying the polymer conformation and packing. However, this process is too fast, and the single-crystalline nature of the samples is easily lost, especially if they are left in air without vapors of the solvent or any special protection. The inverse process, namely, the solvent inclusion, is therefore not possible in single crystals, thus classifying these species as belonging to the first-generation type of porous coordination polymers, according to Kitagawa.

elements.content: Whereas short rigid chains, for example dppa and dppethe, are able to force a polymerization but do not induce porosity properties to the network, alkyl bis-phosphines have the correct length and are able to adapt to the host molecules in their channels, but are probably too flexible, making the releasing process too rapid. Therefore, we are currently investigating some intermediate bis-phosphine ligands, having similar chain lengths but a somewhat lower flexibility; our purpose is to obtain coordination polymers of the third-generation type (i.e., having reversible structural changes upon removal of the guest molecules).
elements.clean_text: Whereas short rigid chains, for example dppa and dppethe, are able to force a polymerization but do not induce porosity properties to the network, alkyl bis-phosphines have the correct length and are able to adapt to the host molecules in their channels, but are probably too flexible, making the releasing process too rapid. Therefore, we are currently investigating some intermediate bis-phosphine ligands, having similar chain lengths but a somewhat lower flexibility; our purpose is to obtain coordination polymers of the third-generation type (i.e., having reversible structural changes upon removal of the guest molecules).

elements.content: Besides their porous properties, the species investigated in this work present a rather interesting polymorphism, either native or induced by external changes as summarized in Scheme . Therefore, we used complementary techniques to characterize not only the polymer structures and crystalline morphologies but also the mechanism of their structural changes. For this reason, the information from polarizing microscopy and modulated differential scanning calorimetry was coupled with X-ray diffraction analysis. In particular, we have shown that polarizing microscopy could be used to detect the paths associated with the solvent evaporation from the crystals and test the degree of crystallinity of the samples subjected to thermal cycles after desolvation.
elements.clean_text: Besides their porous properties, the species investigated in this work present a rather interesting polymorphism, either native or induced by external changes as summarized in Scheme . Therefore, we used complementary techniques to characterize not only the polymer structures and crystalline morphologies but also the mechanism of their structural changes. For this reason, the information from polarizing microscopy and modulated differential scanning calorimetry was coupled with X-ray diffraction analysis. In particular, we have shown that polarizing microscopy could be used to detect the paths associated with the solvent evaporation from the crystals and test the degree of crystallinity of the samples subjected to thermal cycles after desolvation.

elements.content: In future work, we plan to replace the mononuclear metal fragments with transition metal clusters, aiming to obtain more reactive centers at the metal sites and, at the same time, building blocks suitable for three-dimensional porous frameworks.

1,6-Bis(diphenylphosphino)hexane was purchased from Aldrich and used without any further purification.

Synthesis of [RhCl(CO)(<italic toggle="yes">dpphex</italic>)·(<italic toggle="yes">solvent</italic>)]

A dichloromethane solution of [PPh4][RhCl2(CO)2] (74 mg, 0.13 mmol in 2.5 mL) was layered under N2 atmosphere with a tetrahydrofuran solution of dpphex (122 mg, 0.27 mmol in 2.5 mL). ATR-IR: ν̃ cm−1 (CO) 1956 (sh) (Found C, 56.30; H, 5.30; C32H34Cl3OP2Rh requires C, 55.19; H, 4.89).

cln_elements.content: Ball and stick representation of the four conformations that could be adopted by the dpphex ligands about the P−Rh−P axis: (a) eclipsed anticlinal, (b) staggered anti-periplanar (found in polymers 2 and 3), (c) staggered syn-clinal, and (d) eclipsed syn-periplanar (found in the dimer 1a). The dpphex chain is truncated at the third C atom in all drawings. C atoms of the alkyl chains are in blue, C atoms of the phenyl ring in gray, C and O atoms of the carbonyl in red, Cl atoms in green, and P atoms in orange.
